Award.AwardTitle: Empirical Studies of Business-to-Business Bargaining: Evidence from Hospital Input Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intermediate goods markets make up nearly half of U.S. GDP, and prices in these markets are often determined by bargaining between buyers and suppliers. However, few empirical studies have examined intermediate goods markets and negotiated prices. This project aims to study economic and policy questions in intermediate goods markets, using a novel dataset on negotiated prices of medical supplies between hospitals and suppliers. The investigators will examine the role of information, market structures, and healthcare organizations in business-to-business price negotiations. This project will yield new insights into the fundamental determinants of health care costs. The proposed research will also have direct bearing on several current policy debates regarding transparency in hospital supply markets, antitrust treatment of hospitals and physician-hospital relationships, and Medicare reimbursement policy.

This research project consists of three studies that provide one of the first comprehensive studies of markets for hospital supplies and negotiated prices. The first study analyzes the role of information in negotiated prices for coronary stents, using differences-in-differences identification strategies based on both timing of hospitals' joining a benchmarking database and new products entering the market. In the second study, the investigators link bargaining outcomes with market structures and hospital organizational characteristics to test bargaining theory and examine the role of organizational economics and market power in bargaining. The third study combines the hospital purchasing data with changes in Medicare procedure reimbursement to understand how these willingness-to-pay shocks are passed through the vertical supply chain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Business-to-business (B2B) markets, in which buyer firms contract with a set of suppliers to fulfill their input needs, comprise a substantial part of the economy. Prices in these markets are often negotiated between buyers and suppliers, potentially with widely varying prices. The underlying economic mechanisms driving this price dispersion may include: heterogeneous bargaining abilities; heterogenous demand for differentiated products; search/contracting costs for buyers seeking to add a supplier; and strategic exclusion of suppliers. Price dispersion in B2B markets is important because it is typically an indicator of market power, with implications for static and dynamic efficiency. Input prices impact buyer firm profitability in the short run and downstream market efficiency in the long run. 

Over the life of this project, we have developed a series of studies to better understand economic and policy questions in B2Bmarkets, using uniquely detailed data recorded in seven years of purchase orders issued by a large sample of over 1,000 U.S. hospitals. The data used in these studies cover a wide variety of consumable hospital supply markets, ranging from commodities like surgical gloves to expensive, branded surgical implants (known as ?physician preference items,? or PPIs) like coronary stents. These markets exhibit large price dispersion, with coefficients of variation across hospitals for the exact same brand-month in the range 0.05-0.33. Consumable hospital supplies are important inputs in hospital care, representing 23 percent of hospital operating costs. Thus, the variation in these input prices is meaningful in terms of its potential impact on both hospital margins and markets for hospital services. 

In "Transparency and Negotiated Prices: The Value of Information in Hospital-Supplier Bargaining," which has been accepted at the Journal of Political Economy, we examine the role of information in bargaining. Analyzing prices in 37 important product categories before and after sample hospitals purchased access to a subscription benchmarking database, we find that providing hospitals with information on purchasing by peer hospitals leads to price reductions, particularly among hospitals learning that they were previously paying relatively high prices on PPIs purchased in high quantities. The results suggest that benchmarking helps hospitals to resolve an asymmetric information problem. However, price reductions are limited to a subset of hospitals and products and are realized somewhat slowly over time.

In "Mergers and Marginal Costs: New Evidence on Hospital Buyer Power," which is joint with Stuart Craig and currently under review at American Economic Journal: Applied Economics we examine the role of buyer purchasing power in hospital supply negotiations using a large dataset of prices observed before and after horizontal hospital mergers. We find that, for important consumable hospital supplies (which represent perhaps the largest category of unambiguously marginal costs hospitals face), the average merger target in our sample can expect to save 1.9 percent per year, while the average acquirer can expect no savings. Our findings are consistent with mergers inducing an increase in buyer power that is (1) driven by local returns to scale, and (2) more influential for merger targets than for (even small) acquirers. We estimate a positive price effect for large acquirers, consistent with the costs of a merger disrupting management sometimes outweighing any benefit from improved buyer power.

The above two papers find that information and buyer size have statistically significant, but small, effects on the prices of physician preference items, leaving a rather large unexplained price variation residual. In "Diagnosing Price Dispersion: Demand, Bargaining, and Search in Hospital-Supplier Contracting," we build an empirical model of search, bargaining, and demand in order to estimate the relative importance of different frictions in generating price dispersion in heterogeneous product markets. Consistent with the notion that hospitals have limited ability to provide physicians with incentives to reduce costs, we find that utilization of brands in each medical supply category is relatively price-insensitive. We also estimate that search and contracting frictions have a small, but significant, role in generating observed price dispersion. Finally, the bargaining ability of hospital negotiators is estimated to vary widely across hospitals, driving most of the observed price dispersion. Given that bargaining ability is a catch-all parameter that embodies a combination of negotiator skill and the incentives negotiators face as agents of their respective employers, these results suggest that moves to reduce buyer search and contracting costs are unlikely to have much impact in decreasing margins or price dispersion, unless they can help to resolve agency problems.
